channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Security Fears Hang Over African Marathons
item.description: The marathon circuit in Africa has expanded in recent years to countries like Senegal, Nigeria, Ivory Coast and Gabon, despite concerns over potential terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: KEN MAGUIRE
item.media:description: More than 20,000 runners competed in the Lagos City Marathon on Saturday. The marathon circuit in Africa has expanded in recent years to countries including Ghana, Gabon and Ivory Coast, despite fears over the potential for terrorist attacks.

item.title: Young Bombers Kill 58 at Nigerian Camp for Those Fleeing Boko Haram
item.description: The episode at the Dikwa camp follows a pattern of attacks that the group has carried out since the military began operations against the militants.
item.dc:creator: USAM SADIQ AL-AMIN and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: Victims of a bombing at a refugee camp received treatment on Wednesday in Maiduguri, Nigeria.

item.title: Tunisian Town Simmers With Unrest Over Lack of Jobs and Investment
item.description: In a country where nearly a third of young people are unemployed, the jobless in Kasserine have occupied part of the governor’s office and declared a hunger strike.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: The grave of Ridha Yahyaoui, who was electrocuted when he climbed a utility pole during a protest in Tunisia. He quickly became a symbol of popular frustration.

item.title: Ring of Elephant Poachers Broken Up by Tanzanian Authorities
item.description: An inquiry into a British pilot’s death led to nine arrests — including a conservation intelligence officer — on charges of poaching elephants for their ivory.
item.dc:creator: WILLY LOWRY
item.media:description: Elephants at Serengeti National Park in Tanzania. The elephant population in the country fell to 43,000 in June 2015 from 109,000 in 2009.

item.title: Guantánamo Prisoner Sent Home to Morocco Remains in Legal Limbo
item.description: Younis Shokuri feared being repatriated to Morocco, and his lawyers said they were assured there was a deal between the U.S. and Moroccan governments. Yet he remains in custody in his native country.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE and AIDA ALAMI
item.media:description: Thirty-four of the 91 remaining detainees at the Guantánamo prison have been recommended for transfer.

item.title: world briefing: Nigeria: Separatist Groups Deny Any Role in Ship’s Hijacking
item.description: Claims that the ship was boarded last week by separatists are probably a cover to lend legitimacy to a kidnapping for ransom, a maritime security expert said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: world briefing: Somalia: Residue From Explosives Found in Jet, Airline Says
item.description: The top executive of the airline, whose jetliner was damaged in an explosion shortly after takeoff this week, cautioned that the findings were inconclusive.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Obama Is Pressed to Open Military Front Against ISIS in Libya
item.description: The number of Islamic State fighters in Libya has grown to between 5,000 and 6,500, Pentagon officials said, more than double the estimate of last fall.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Zubaydi, Wissam Najm Abd Zayd al
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Militia fighters aligned with the forces that took over the government in Tripoli, Libya, fired an artillery piece at Islamic State militants near Surt last year.

item.title: U.N. Report Accuses Rwanda of Training Rebels to Oust Burundian Leader
item.description: The report said investigators had spoken with 18 Burundian rebels who claimed to have been trained inside Rwanda.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: U.N. Peacekeepers Accused of Rape in Central African Republic
item.description: A Human Rights Watch report on abuse by peacekeepers in Central African Republic added to what the United Nations has called a serious problem.
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Matter: DNA Study of First Ancient African Genome Flawed, Researchers Report
item.description: When other researchers studied the 4,500-year-old-genome, they discovered that the conclusion that much of Africa has Eurasian ancestry was incorrect.
item.dc:creator: CARL ZIMMER
item.media:description: After David Reich and a colleague requested the original data from a report about the first ancient human genome found in Africa, they discovered a flaw in the study’s conclusions.

item.title: Bomb Suspected in Deadly Explosion on Somali Jet
item.description: The blast above the plane’s right wing on Tuesday sucked one passenger out, killing him, and injured two others. Shabab militants are suspected.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Jacob Zuma, South African Leader, to Repay Part of Money Spent on His Home
item.description: The president has been dogged by reports about $23 million in public funds used to make extensive upgrades to his homestead.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: The lavish home of South Africa’s president, Jacob Zuma, top, in Nkandla, in 2012.

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Ship’s Hijackers Make a Threat
item.description: Nigerian separatists threatened to blow up a merchant ship if the authorities do not release a separatist leader seeking the independence of Biafra.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Plane Lands After Explosion
item.description: The plane, operated by Daallo Airlines and headed to Djibouti, was forced to land minutes after taking off from Mogadishu.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Muslim Conference Calls for Protection of Religious Minorities
item.description: The gathering in Morocco of muftis, theologians and scholars issued a declaration welcomed by many as a hopeful sign, though also seen with some skepticism.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: AIDA ALAMI
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yazidis from Sinjar Province in Iraq after their arrival on the Greek island of Lesbos from Turkey in November.

item.title: 18 Elephants on a Plane: Move From Swaziland to U.S. Is Criticized
item.description: Three zoos formed a partnership to house the elephants, which were said to be threatened by habitat destruction and drought, but conservationists said the move imperiled the animals.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.media:description: In 2003, animal and elephant welfare groups opposed a plan to move 11 elephants from this group in Swaziland to the United States.

item.title: Anti-ISIS Coalition to Intensify Efforts, John Kerry Says
item.description: The secretary of state said the formation of a national unity government in Libya would prevent the Islamic State from seizing control of the country.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: My Secret Policeman
item.description: In Egypt, if a National Security officer calls to ask you ‘to tea,’ it’s an invitation you can’t refuse.
item.dc:creator: MONA ELTAHAWY

item.title: World Briefing: Ivory Coast: Gbago Was a Defender of Democracy, Lawyer Tells Court
item.description: A defense lawyer made the argument in his opening statement at Laurent Gbagbo’s trial on charges of crimes against humanity.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
